title-group.article-title: Multi-point robust design optimization of wind turbine airfoil under geometric uncertainty

abstract.p: Modern wind turbine airfoil designs are increasingly emphasizing low sensitivity to the leading edge roughness in addition to good aerodynamic performances under varying wind conditions. In this study, a multi-point robust design optimization method has been systematically established for the wind turbine airfoil. The objective is to not only maximize the lift-to-drag ratio and lift coefficient at and near the design point, but also minimize their sensitivity to the leading edge roughness associated with the geometry profile uncertainty. The geometry parameterization of the airfoil is conducted by the Bezier curves. In the robust optimization, the multi-objective genetic algorithm, Monte Carlo simulation technique, and artificial neural network model are used. The results show that both the robust Pareto optimal (RPO) and deterministic Pareto optimal (DPO) airfoils have higher lift-to-drag ratio and lift coefficient than the original design FX 63-137 at and near the design point. A smaller maximum camber and larger radii near the leading edge help the RPO airfoil outperform both the DPO and original ones in terms of low sensitivity to the leading edge roughness. This study may be useful to the future development of the wind turbine airfoils with higher efficiency and reliability.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Design of good performance and reliable airfoils for wind turbine blades is one of the key elements in the wind energy technology. During the last decade, a series of increasingly rigorous design guidelines have been proposed for the wind turbine airfoil by some national energy laboratories and international standardization commissions [1–3]. These guidelines can be expressed as a matrix of structural, aerodynamic, and aero-acoustic performances at the root, mid-part, and tip blade airfoils, respectively. All the performances are closely related to the aerodynamic design methods and their sensitivity analysis.

In particular, the presence of small but random perturbations such as the manufacturing errors, blade erosion, or dirt/bug deposition on the airfoil leading edge may cause a drastic deterioration in the aerodynamic performance of the wind turbine [4]. In this case, the most suitable design method for the wind turbine airfoil should be the robust design optimization (RDO). The essential function of the RDO is to find out the balanced designs between the optimality and robustness, expecting not only the minimum or maximum objectives, but also the minimum sensitivity of the objectives to the uncertainties of design variables.

The early wind turbine airfoils primarily derived themselves from some low-speed aviation airfoils, such as the Wortmann FX-77 and NASA LS(1) airfoils. Since the mid-1980s, substantial efforts have been devoted to the development of wind turbine-dedicated airfoils. Some governmental agencies, academic institutions, and industrial manufacturers have developed several wind turbine airfoil families. These include National Renewable Energy Laboratory (previously Solar Energy Research Institute) airfoils by Tangler and Somers [5], Flygtekniska f⊙rsöksantalten (FFA) airfoils (Aeronautical Research Institute of Sweden) by Björk [6], Delf University (DU) airfoils by Timmer and Van Rooij [7], and Risø airfoils by Fuglsang and Bak [8].

The tailored wind turbine airfoils have their common advantages over the early aviation ones in terms of the superior performance at low wind speed and lower sensitivity to the leading edge roughness. Most of the wind turbine airfoils were developed by means of the traditional inverse design methods [9–11] or deterministic design optimization (DDO) methods [12, 13]; the sensitivity assessment was often neglected or conducted by either wind tunnel experiments or designer’s individual experience. Particularly, Fuglsang and Madsen [13] optimized the horizontal axis wind turbines by the SIMPLEX algorithm, a gradient-based optimizer. Later on, they incorporated the sensitivity concept into the DDO method in such a way that the transition from the laminar to turbulent flow occurred virtually at the leading edge [8]. A similar sensitivity design technique was also adopted for DU airfoils by Timmer and van Rooij [7]. Nevertheless, these heuristic sensitivity design methods cannot provide the robust optimal solutions. To the best of our knowledge, no open efforts have been devoted to the RDO of the wind turbine airfoil based on the statistical theory.

Egorov et al. [14] overviewed the basic principles of the RDO. Some RDO algorithms and applications have been used for the aerodynamic design of gas turbine blade airfoils and aircraft airfoils [15–18]. One of the daunting tasks in the simulation-based design optimization is how to perform an inexpensive evaluation of the objectives for the thousands of intermediate samples, while the RDO further complicates this issue due to the additional probabilistic estimation of the objectives for each of the intermediate samples. In this respect, Wang and Shan [19] reviewed the numerous metamodels which can serve as the surrogate of the expensive simulation process to improve the overall computation efficiency. To date, the Kriging model technique has been widely used in the robust optimization [20, 21]. However, the Kriging models are generally difficult to obtain and use because a global optimization process is applied to identify the maximum likelihood estimators [19]. The intention of this study is to demonstrate the feasibility and efficiency of the artificial neural network (ANN) model for the RDO problem. The most attractive advantage of the ANNs is their availability for the multivariate non-linear problems with no need to assume an underlying data distribution as usually done in the statistical modelling [19–22]. Here, the ANN models are developed as the approximate fast flow solver and replace the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) calculations to predict the aerodynamic performances for the wind turbine airfoil under the geometry uncertainty at and near the design point.

The multi-objective genetic algorithm (MOGA) is used to solve the RDO problem for the wind turbine airfoils at the multiple points. The MOGA optimizer outperforms the SIMPLEX method in terms of escaping from the local extrema, and thus finds out the global optimal solutions. Apart from maximizing the lift-to-drag ratio and lift coefficient at and near the design point, the RDO also aims to minimize their sensitivity to the leading edge roughness where the geometric uncertainty is considered for the wind turbine airfoils. The stochastic sampling and statistical averaging are performed using the Monte Carlo simulation (MCS) method. The addition of the sensitivity criterion into the objectives leads to a series of robust Pareto optimal (RPO) solutions, which reveal the trade-offs between the optimality and robustness. On the contrary, those deterministic Pareto optimal (DPO) solutions obtained without this criterion may suffer from a heavy discount once subject to the uncertain perturbations in real life. The differences between the RPO and DPO solutions are clearly demonstrated in this study.

This paper is organized into the following sections. Section 2 presents the multi-point RDO problem for the wind turbine airfoil. Section 3 outlines the optimization methods. The relevant numerical implementation flowchart is illustrated in section 4. In section 5, the DPO, RPO, and original airfoils are discussed in detail using the CFD simulation and MCS analysis. Some conclusions are drawn in section 6.

sec.title: 2.1 Airfoil parameterization
sec.p: The airfoil parameterization plays an important part in the automated definition of new geometries in the optimization procedure. Several methods for the airfoil parameterization are currently available, such as Bezier curves, B-splines, Hicks-Henne functions, and radial base functions. At present, the wind turbine airfoil is parameterized by the Bezier curves. The most attractive advantage of a Bezier curve is its flexible description of a family of airfoils through only a few control points. Generally, the Bezier curve of degree n can be defined as follows: (1) where t ranges from 0 to 1, P(t) is the x- or y-coordinate of any point on the curve, B the Bernstein basis function, Cn i the combination number, and Qi the x- or y-coordinate of the control point i. Accordingly, the Bezier curve can be determined if and only if the control points are specified [23].

The Bezier curves are used to parameterize the camber line and thickness distribution of axial compressor blade airfoil in the previous work [24, 25]. Here, the wind turbine airfoil contour is directly modelled. As shown in Fig. 1, two Bezier curves of degree seven are used to parameterize the upper and lower surfaces of the wind turbine airfoil, respectively. Suppose the Points 1 and 8 are fixed, the number of the independent control points will add up to 12. Besides, the Points 1, 2, and 14 are assumed to be collinear to guarantee the smoothness of the leading edge. Similar assumption is also made for the Points 7, 8, and 9 at the trailing edge. Fig. 1
Parameterization of the airfoil FX 63-137 using Bezier curves

The reverse calculation of the Bezier control points is based on the least square method. It is interesting to note that this parameterization technique can be quite accurate for recreating the existing airfoils. In Fig. 1, the generated Bezier curves are fairly consistent with the contour of the airfoil FX 63-137 [26]. Hereafter, this generated airfoil is used as the original one to be optimized.

sec.title: 2.2 CFD simulation methods
sec.p: The CFD methods are used to calculate the aerodynamic performance of the ANN training and test samples, and to simulate the detailed flow fields for the airfoils. Suppose the flow is incompressible due to the low-velocity flow, the two-dimensional unsteady Navier–Stokes equations read [27] (2) where Φ=(1,U,V,νt)T, and thus equation (2) stands for the continuity equation, momentum equations along x- and y-coordinates, and turbulent viscosity equation. The governing equations are discretized by the finite volume method with the pressure-based SIMPLE algorithm. The unsteady term is discretized by the two-order implicit scheme, the convection term by the two-order upwind scheme and the diffusion term by the two-order central scheme. The Spalart–Allmaras model is used to close the turbulence terms.

To simulate the far flow field condition, the computational inlet is placed at about 12.5 chord upstream of the airfoil and outlet about 20 chord downstream of the airfoil (Fig. 2). The boundary condition at the inlet is the flow velocity, U∞, and angle, β∞, while the static pressure, Ps, is specified at the outlet. The non-slip solid boundary condition is adopted on the airfoil surface. Fig. 2
The computational domain

As Fig. 3 shows, the C type grid is generated in the computational region. The grid independency is examined via successively reducing the grid size on the airfoil surface until the evaluated aerodynamic quantity is essentially no longer changed. Thus, the area-averaged y+ of the first inner nodes close to the airfoil surface is 1.35; the total number of the grid points is 153 on the airfoil surface and 35 783 all over the computational region. More details of this CFD method can be found in the study done by Zhang et al. [28]. For a further validation, the lift and drag coefficients of the airfoil FX 63-137 are calculated using the CFD method at a Reynolds number of 200082. As shown in Fig. 4, the CFD results agree well with the experimental data, especially around the design point. Fig. 3

sec.title: 2.3.1 Objectives
sec.p:
A desired wind turbine airfoil should hold both good aerodynamic performance and low sensitivity to the leading edge roughness in the varying wind environments. The aerodynamic performance of the original airfoil is first evaluated using the CFD simulation methods. The upstream flow angle, β∞, varies from 0° to 15° with velocity magnitude U∞ 12.3 m/s, and the outlet static pressure is 101 325 Pa. As seen in Fig. 5, the original airfoil reaches the maximum lift-to-drag ratio Cl/Cd, i.e. 55.57 at the design point (β∞ = 4°), where the lift coefficient Cl is about 1.29. Fig. 5
The aerodynamic performance curves of the original wind turbine airfoil

To minimize the stochastic influence from the varying wind, the averaged aerodynamic performances are optimized for the wind turbine airfoil at and near the design point. The considered wind variations are ±1 m/s for U∞ and ±1° for β∞ around the design point. Accordingly, a total of nine working point performances are calculated in the optimization, as listed in Table 1. Due to the inevitable manufacturing errors, erosion, or dirt, the wind turbine airfoils often show distributed roughness on the airfoil surface, especially near the leading edge. That is why the wind turbine airfoils are particularly required to have low sensitivity to the leading edge roughness in addition to superior aerodynamic performances. In this study, the airfoil roughness is particularly characterized by the stochastic geometry profile variations near the leading edge. The probabilistic estimation is embedded in the optimization to model and assess the effects of these geometric uncertainties by converting the deterministic optimization problem into the robust optimization problem. Here, both the means and standard deviations of the Cl/Cd¯ and Cl¯ are to be optimized. Overall, the objectives are summarized as follows.
Objective 1: to maximize the mean lift-to-drag ratio, viz.
max μ(Cl/Cd¯)
Objective 2: to maximize the mean lift coefficient, viz.
max μ(Cl¯)
Objective 3: to minimize the standard deviation of the lift-to-drag ratio, viz.
min σ(Cl/Cd¯)
Objective 4: to minimize the standard deviation of the lift coefficient, viz.
min σ(Cl¯)

sec.title: 2.3.2 Design variables
sec.p:
Although up to 12 control points have been used in Fig. 1 to parameterize the wind turbine airfoil FX 63-137, only 4 of them are varied during the present optimization, i.e. the Points 2, 3, 12, and 14. These four points primarily control the geometric shape at and near the leading edge of the airfoil, thus significantly influencing the aerodynamic performance of the wind turbine airfoil. To simplify the problem, the y-coordinates of the four control points are extracted as the design variables while keeping their x-coordinates unchanged. As mentioned in the last section, the airfoil roughness is considered with respect to the geometry profile uncertainty. Actually, it is difficult, if not impossible, to measure the exact profile of this dimensional uncertainty. In that case, the concept of probability density distribution is adopted to describe the geometric uncertainty for each design variable. As shown in Fig. 6, a rectangular distribution profile is assumed [29], the width of which is set to be a tolerance of 10 per cent the variation range. Fig. 6

sec.title: 3 OPTIMIZATION METHODS
sec.p: The present RDO of wind turbine airfoils is in essence a multi-objective optimization problem, which is solved by referring to the MOGA [30]. Based on the genetic algorithm (GA) [31], the MOGA is capable of finding out the global maximum or minimum of the objectives in the design space rather than get trapped into a local extremum. However, the optimizing process may be quite computationally expensive, particularly for the robust multi-objective optimization problem. This is mainly because the embedded probabilistic estimation method such as the MCS often requires a large number of random airfoil samples under geometry uncertainty. To avoid this prohibitive simulation cost, the ANN technique is employed as a metamodel to replace the CFD calculations in the optimization process.

sec.title: 3.1 Multi-objective genetic algorithm
sec.p: In the implementation of the MOGA, three techniques are used to promote the population evolution, i.e. the Pareto ranking technique, the diversity-preserving technique, and the optimum reservation strategy. As a result, a series of Pareto optimum solutions are obtained; neither can dominate the others for all the criterions. Decision makers can then choose their favourite one according to different practical applications.

The Pareto ranking technique is first proposed by Goldberg [31], for the purpose of classifying and ranking the entire population to determine whether one individual is better than the other. First, the Pareto solutions are defined as the best solutions and assigned the highest rank of No. 1, and then removed from the population; afterwards, another set of Pareto solutions are identified and removed from the remaining population as the solutions of rank 2, i.e. the second highest rank; the search for the next best solutions continues until all the solutions is ranked. Note, the solutions of a higher rank are better than those of a lower rank, and more likely to be selected for the offspring reproduction.

The diversity-preserving technique used in the MOGA can make the Pareto distribution more uniform and representative, and so contribute to a rapid and convenient decision-making. Goldberg and Richardson [32] have proposed the use of a sharing function to measure the similarity between any two individuals, and thus to modify their fitness values. An individual, A, with a larger sharing value implies more individuals similar to A. In that case, A will get fewer possibilities of reproduction.

During the implementation of the MOGA, the current Pareto optimum solutions often suffer from degeneration once they are involved in producing offsprings, thus leading to the failure of finding the true optimum solutions. To tackle this problem, an optimum reservation strategy has been proposed, whereby the current Pareto optimum solutions are copied to an additional space, the so-called gene pool, without imposing any interference on the evolution; the true Pareto optimum solutions emerge from the final competition among the reserved optimums [24].

sec.title: 3.2 Probabilistic estimation method
sec.p: The distinct feature of the RDO problem is the probabilistic estimation of the criterions for any intermediate sample in the optimization process. Several classes of methods are currently available to facilitate this estimation, such as the MCS [33], sensitivity-based estimation method [34], and polynomial chaos expansion [35]. In this study, the MCS is implemented to calculate the statistical nature of the criterion, such as the mean, μ, and standard deviation, σ. To ensure the accuracy of the MCS, sufficient sample points should be randomly generated according to the specified probabilistic distribution of the variables. To alleviate the computational burden of the simulation process, the ANN model is constructed, as described below, to serve as the approximate fast flow solver instead of the accurate but costly CFD calculation.

To increase the ANN prediction accuracy, the uniform design of experiment (DOE) method [36, 37] is employed to provide the appropriate representative training samples for the ANN model. In an uniform DOE table Un(qs), n denotes the experiment sample number, q the factor number, and s the level number. During the training process of the ANN model, the GA technique is used to optimize the initial weights, which is proved beneficial to the higher efficiency of the BP algorithm. The developed ANN model is termed as the DOE-based GA-BP-ANN model [24].

sec.title: 4 NUMERICAL IMPLEMENTATION
sec.p:
Figure 8 illustrates the flowchart of the RDO for the wind turbine airfoils. As described in the definition of the design problem, special attention has been focused on optimizing the statistical natures of the Cl/Cd and Cl for the wind turbine airfoil. Two separate ANN models are developed to quickly approximate the Cl/Cd and Cl, respectively, for the stochastic wind turbine airfoil under the nine wind conditions. Both models share the same network construction of 6-6-1, i.e. six neurons in the input layer, six in the hidden layer, and one in the output layer. In the input layer, four neurons are assigned for the geometric design variables whereas the other two for the wind conditions, i.e. U∞ and β∞. The output neuron corresponds to the prediction value of the Cl/Cd or Cl. Fig. 8
The flowchart of the RDO for the wind turbine airfoils

According to the uniform DOE table U60(66), 60 airfoils are generated as the ANN training samples. Another set of airfoils is also obtained using the uniform DOE table U30(306) to test the ANN prediction accuracy.

The aerodynamic performances for the training and test samples are first calculated by the CFD simulation method. Then, the GA-BP algorithm is implemented to build the ANN models using the training samples. The maximum value of the criterion E (equation (11)) is set to be 10−4, within engineering tolerance.

With the help of the DOE-based GA-BP-ANN model, the process of the MCS is fairly computationally inexpensive for the probabilistic estimation of the objectives. Here, the MCS sample size NMC (equations (8) and (9)) is set to be 1000 after confirming that almost the same results can be obtained when using a larger value.

In the MOGA optimization, the population size of the evolution is set to be 100 and the maximum number of generation to be 500. The optimization process is iterated until the trade-off among the four objectives has converged, and thus the RPO solutions are obtained.

To demonstrate the effectiveness of the above RDO of the wind turbine airfoils, the DDO is additionally conducted without considering the geometric uncertainty. Therefore, only two objectives, i.e. Cl/Cd¯ and Cl¯ are involved in the search of the DPO solutions.

sec.title: 5.1 Accuracy of ANN models
sec.p:
As described above, two DOE-based GA-BP-ANN models are constructed to predict the Cl/Cd and Cl of the wind turbine airfoil, respectively. Figure 9 gives a quantitative evaluation on how well the ANN predictions fit the CFD simulation results of the test samples. The maximum prediction error is kept below 0.09 per cent for the Cl/Cd and 0.06 per cent for the Cl, which confirms the accuracy and efficiency of the constructed ANN models to facilitate the RDO of the wind turbine airfoil. Fig. 9
The ANN test results for the lift-to-drag ratio (a) and lift coefficient (b)

sec.title: 5.2 RPO and DPO solutions
sec.p:
Using the MOGA optimizer, a series of RPO solutions have been obtained, which distribute in the four-dimensional objective space. These RPO solutions are put onto two different planes to obtain a clear observation. As shown in Fig. 10, both planes share the same μ(Cl/Cd¯) and μ(Cl¯) axes, while the colour bars are assigned to denote the values of σ(Cl/Cd¯) andσ(Cl¯), respectively. Thus, the trade-off relations among the four objectives can be clearly visualized. It is also practically feasible for decision-makers to choose suitable solutions according to different preferences. Fig. 10
The RPO distribution in terms of μ(Cl/Cd¯),μ(Cl¯) and σ(Cl/Cd¯)(a) and μ(Cl/Cd¯), μ(Cl¯), and σ(Cl¯)(b)

To understand the compromise between the optimality and robustness of the aerodynamic performances, the probabilistic evaluation is performed on the DPO solutions, as shown in Fig. 11. It is interesting to remark that the upper branch of the RPO solutions is actually similar to the DPO solutions, which are characterized by the superior aerodynamic performances. For the lower branch of the RPO solutions, priorities are given to minimize the two standard deviation values. Although the lower branch of the RPO solutions seem inferior to the upper ones in terms of the μ(Cl/Cd¯) and μ(Cl¯), they indeed achieve smaller σ(Cl/Cd¯) and σ(Cl¯), reflecting the essential requirement of the RDO for less sensitivity to the geometry profile uncertainty in the practical wind turbine engineering. Fig. 11
The probabilistic estimation of the DPO solutions in terms of μ(Cl/Cd¯), μ(Cl¯) and σ(Cl/Cd¯) (a) and μ(Cl/Cd¯), μ(Cl¯), and σ(Cl¯)(b)

sec.title: 5.2.1 Comparison between RPO, DPO, and original airfoils: CFD results
sec.p:
To deepen insight into the aerodynamic performance of the optimized wind turbine airfoils, the detailed CFD simulations and MCS analysis are performed in this and the next sections, respectively.
The original airfoil, i.e. FX 63-137 airfoil.
A DPO solution as starred in Fig. 11, which strikes a good balance between the robustness criterions of μ(Cl/Cd¯) and μ(Cl¯)
A RPO solution as encircled in Fig. 10, which strikes a good balance between the robustness criterions of σ(Cl/Cd¯) and σ(Cl¯)

The contours of all the three airfoils are depicted in Fig. 12, and the corresponding coordinates are listed in Table 3. It can be seen that both the DPO and RPO airfoils are more slender, with almost identical pressure surfaces thinner than that of the original airfoil. The main differences are noticeable at the suction surface: compared with the original airfoil, the RPO airfoil has a smaller maximum camber and larger curvature radii near the leading edge whereas the DPO airfoil is just the opposite, whose maximum camber is slightly increased and the curvature radii near the leading edge is reduced. Fig. 12
Geometry comparison between the original, DPO, and RPO airfoils

Figures 13 and 14 show the CFD simulation results of the three airfoils at the nine working points stated in Table 1. As can be seen, the two optimized airfoils can outperform the original one for higher Cl/Cd and Cl at all the nine points, indicating the success of the optimization methods. Besides, the DPO airfoil can achieve even higher Cl/Cd and Cl than the RPO airfoil at the nine points. Fig. 13
The lift-to-drag ratios of the original (a), DPO (b), and RPO airfoils (c) at the nine working points Fig. 14
The lift coefficients of the original (a), DPO (b), and RPO airfoils (c) at the nine working points

Generally, the premature transition has harmful effects on the airfoil aerodynamic performance, such as the increase in drag and decrease in lift and lift-drag-ratio. However, it is interesting to note that the nowadays wind turbine airfoils have been particularly designed with a premature transition point at the nose [7] or the leading edge [8] in order to lower the sensitivity to the leading edge roughness. Together with our RDO practice and CFD simulation, it is concluded that a wind turbine airfoil could achieve low sensitivity to the leading edge roughness at the expense of its aerodynamic performance.

sec.title: 5.2.2 Comparison between RPO, DPO, and original airfoils: MCS results
sec.p:
In this section, the MCS analysis is carried out to validate the probabilistic characteristics of the above three airfoils at the nine points, respectively. Considering the geometric uncertainties, totally 1000 independent perturbations have been made to each of the airfoils. For the limited space, only some typical probabilistic distributions of the aerodynamic performances are given instead of all those at the nine points (Figs 17 to 19). Fig. 17
MCS validations of the lift-to-drag ratio (a) and lift coefficient (b) for the original, DPO, and RPO airfoils at U∞ = 11.3 m/s, β∞ = 3° Fig. 18
MCS validations of the lift-to-drag ratio (a) and lift coefficient (b) for the original, DPO, and RPO airfoils at U∞ = 12.3 m/s, β∞ = 4° (design point) Fig. 19
MCS validations of the lift-to-drag ratio (a) and lift coefficient (b) for the original, DPO, and RPO airfoils at U∞ = 13.3°m/s, β∞ = 5°

Compared with the other two airfoils, the RPO airfoil has relatively peaked probabilistic distributions around the mean aerodynamic performance values, which lie between those of the DPO and original airfoils. Although the RPO airfoil fails to attain the optimal Cl/Cd and Cl, the smaller maximum camber and larger leading edge radii can fairly benefit a lower sensitivity to the leading edge roughness at and near the design point. Thus, the robust optimal airfoil is demonstrated to be more reliable than the deterministic optimal airfoil. Actually, it is this particular superiority that enables the RPO airfoil to be more appreciated in the practical wind turbine engineering.

Here, it has to be remarked that this study focuses on the RDO of the wind turbine airfoil under geometric uncertainty at and near the design point. To the best of our knowledge, good stall characteristics and their sensitivity analysis are also essential for the wind turbine airfoils. The future work will examine the maximum lift coefficient Cl,max in the robust optimization of the wind turbine airfoil.

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: A multi-point RDO method has been established for the wind turbine airfoil under geometry uncertainty. In addition to maximizing the Cl/Cd and Cl of the wind turbine airfoil at and near the design point, the sensitivity to the leading edge roughness associated with the geometry profile uncertainty is particularly minimized. The MCS technique is applied to the probabilistic estimation of the criterions in the optimization. To alleviate the computational burden of the robust optimization process, DOE-based GA-BP-ANN models are constructed to quickly predict the aerodynamic performances of the wind turbine airfoils. The DDO is also conducted to provide the comparative results.

The ANN predictions are demonstrated to agree well with the CFD simulation results of the test samples. From the detailed CFD and MCS validations, both the RPO and DPO airfoils can outperform the original one in terms of higher Cl/Cd and Cl at the nine working conditions. Although the RPO airfoil has less significant improvements in the Cl/Cd and Cl than the DPO airfoil, a smaller maximum camber and larger radii near the leading edge make the RPO airfoil more reliable and acceptable, with much lower sensitivity to the leading edge roughness. This finding may benefit the future development of the wind turbine airfoils with higher efficiency and reliability.
It is worth noting that the systematic methodology established here is fairly generic and can be extended to the more complex RDO problems in the wind turbine engineering design.
